Question: I have defined several layouts, where few id's are multiple defined. I am confused how does it work? why doesn't it give error just like we get in java code? and most importantly, how does environment decide to which component it needs to invoke? I understand the process of id generation is automated, which gets added to R.java For instance, if we have same IDs, say "image1" in two XMLs, say "layout1" & "layout2". but in R.java it won't have 2 IDs. that means at a time it will reference only 1 component. In case we have to use 2 XMLs in an Activity, one as activity.setcontentview(layout1) and another as a PopupWindow.setContentView(layout2). What will happen in such case?

The Android system automatically generates unique IDs for each view in the layout. When you inflate a layout, the system maps the IDs in the layout to the corresponding View objects in your code. This allows you to find and interact with those views later in your code.

In your case, if you have the same ID in two different layouts, the system will only keep the reference to the first view it encounters with that ID. The second view with the same ID will be ignored.

When you call setContentView() with a new layout, the system replaces the old layout with the new one. This means that the old views are no longer accessible, and any references to them will be null.

In your second question, the error you're seeing is likely because you're trying to call a method on a null object. The MediaPlayer object is not being initialized before you try to call methods on it. You should initialize it in the onCreate() method, before you try to play any sounds.
